titleInfo.title: Parent-Reported Levels of Anxiety in Children with Special Education Classifications

name.namePart: Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems

mods:mods.abstract: Elementary school children with academic challenges are often provided special education services. These services are meant to support children in their academic goals, through either academic intervention (e.g., reading or math) or physical aids (e.g., extra test time, larger fonts). Being classified as eligible for receiving special education services has been shown to be associated with a child's mental health. One potential outcome is higher levels of anxiety. Children worry about their academic disparity and about how they may be ostracized from their peers, given their label of requiring special education. All these factors could increase their risk for developing higher levels of anxiety. To explore associations of special education participation and anxiety in children, I used archival elementary grades follow up data from a larger intervention study conducted with children during preschool; the follow up outcome of interest is child anxiety symptoms as rated through parent report. The data were analyzed through three ANCOVAs to explore the relationship between special education classifications and anxiety levels. I found non-significant results between children receiving special education classifications of any kind on parent-reported anxiety levels. When I compared individual classifications clusters to no special education classifications, I found significant results between children who were classified as having a combination of physical and cognitive special education classifications on parent-reported anxiety levels. Lastly, I found non-significant results for the relation between the age children began receiving special education classifications and anxiety levels. All of this concludes in a complex picture of special education classifications on parent-reported anxiety levels. Further research is required to discover if special education classifications work as a protective factor or a risk factor for child anxiety levels.
mods:mods.note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Education.
Beth M. Phillips, Professor Directing Thesis; Alysia D. Roehrig, Committee Member; Yanyun Yang, Committee Member.
